bill.title: AN ACT CONCERNING SECURITY FREEZES ON CREDIT REPORTS, IDENTITY THEFT PREVENTION SERVICES AND REGULATIONS OF CREDIT RATING AGENCIES.
bill.abstract: To (1) prohibit credit rating agencies from charging a fee to consumers to place or remove a security freeze from the consumer's account, (2) require credit rating agencies to notify other credit rating agencies of a consumer's request to place or remove a security freeze from such consumer's account, and (3) increase the amount of identity theft prevention or mitigation services provided after a security breach.

bill.title: AN ACT TO AMEND TITLE 4 OF THE DELAWARE CODE RELATING TO CONCENTRATED ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE.
bill.abstract: This Act makes it unlawful for a person to manufacture, distribute, sell, offer for sale, possess, purchase, or use a concentrated alcoholic beverage. This Act also makes technical corrections to conform existing law to the standards of the Delaware Legislative Drafting Manual.

status.statusval: Amendment HA 1 to HB 372 - Introduced and Placed With Bill

profile.pname: Heineken|General|Trade Practices and License to Operate

bill.title: AN ACT TO AMEND TITLE 18 OF THE DELAWARE CODE RELATING TO PHARMACY BENEFIT MANAGER PRIOR AUTHORIZATION OF EMERGENCY PRESCRIPTIONS AND PRESCRIPTIONS FOR CHRONIC OR LONG-TERM CONDITIONS.
bill.abstract: Due to the delay in the prior authorization process by pharmacy benefit managers, many patients end up waiting days to weeks for medications to be filled that are prescribed on an emergency basis or for medications that have been previously prescribed for chronic and long-term conditions that must go through the prior authorization process again. To reduce the delay and hardship of this waiting process, this bill will put into place specified time tables to fill emergency prescriptions and to make subsequent prior authorizations for chronic and long-term conditions to be filled more readily.

status.statusval: Introduced and Assigned to Economic Development/Banking/Insurance/Commerce Committee in House

bill.title: AN ACT TO AMEND TITLE 18, TITLE 29, AND TITLE 31 OF THE DELAWARE CODE RELATING TO INSURANCE COVERAGE OF CONTRACEPTIVES.
bill.abstract: Birth control use is nearly universal among women of reproductive age in the United States and is a key part of preventative health care for women. Access to birth control provides health benefits for women and children, improves women's ability to control whether and when they have a child, and fosters women's ability to participate in education and the workforce. However, the cost of birth control, particularly the higher up-front costs of the more effective, longer-acting birth control methods, is often a barrier to women accessing the birth control they need. This Act codifies the current federal requirement that health insurance plans include coverage for contraceptives and applies this requirement to individual, group, State employee, and public assistance plans. This Act retains the ...

status.statusval: Passed By Senate. Votes: 17 YES 4 NO

bill.title: AN ACT TO AMEND TITLE 6 AND TITLE 26 OF THE DELAWARE CODE RELATING TO THE PUBLIC SERVICE COMMISSION AND THE REGULATION OF MOTOR VEHICLE DEALERS AND PUBLIC UTILITIES.
bill.abstract: The Public Service Commission's (""PSC"") authority over public utilities has been changed by recent decisions by the Federal Communications Commission (""FCC"") and legislation enacted in Delaware. This Act changes the statutory requirements for PSC public utilities to remove requirements that are no longer consistent with the FCC decisions and revised State laws but impose unnecessary burdens and costs on utilities and administrative costs to the PSC. This Act also removes an unnecessary administrative requirement regarding motor vehicle dealers. The specific changes are as follows: Section 1. Removes the requirement in 4915 of Title 6 that an annual assessment be sent to motor vehicle dealers so that the PSC has the flexibility to send an annual assessment and notification to motor ...

status.statusval: Introduced and Assigned to Environmental, Natural Resources & Energy Committee in Senate

bill.title: AN ACT TO AMEND TITLE 16, TITLE 18, AND TITLE 29 OF THE DELAWARE CODE RELATING TO PRIMARY CARE SERVICES.
bill.abstract: This Act promotes the use of primary care by doing the following: 1. Creating a Primary Care Reform Collaborative under the Delaware Health Care Commission. 2. Requiring all health insurance providers to participate in the Delaware Health Care Claims Database. 3. Requiring individual, group, and State employee plans to reimburse physicians for Chronic Care Management and primary care at no less than the Medicare rate for the next 3 years. Despite the demonstrated value of primary care, access to primary care for Delawareans has become increasingly difficult because insurance reimbursement rates fail to support an adequate infrastructure. The national average for primary care spending for an insurance plan is between 6% and 8% of the insurer's total medical expenditures. Studies recommend, ...

bill.title: AN ACT TO AMEND TITLES 16 AND 29 OF THE DELAWARE CODE RELATING TO THE RESTORATION OF THE DELAWARE PRESCRIPTION DRUG PAYMENT ASSISTANCE PROGRAM.
bill.abstract: This Act restores the Delaware Prescription Drug Payment Assistance Program (""Program""), which was eliminated in the Fiscal Year 2018 Annual Appropriations Act. This Act replaces Senate Bill 148 and makes the following additional changes: (1) Delays implementation of the Act until January 1, 2019, to coordinate with the Medicare Part D benefit year to enable the Department of Health and Social Services (""Department"") to make necessary system changes. (2) Makes changes to the defined term ""prescription drugs."" (3) Removes provisions required to be included in rules and regulations promulgated by the Department. (4) Adds provisions that may be included in rules and regulations promulgated by the Department. (5) Makes technical corrections to conform the provisions of the restored Program to ...

bill.title: RELATING TO ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION.
bill.abstract: Renames the Carbon Farming Task Force established by Act 33, Session Laws of Hawaii 2017, as the Greenhouse Gas Sequestration Task Force and makes the task force and Hawaii Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation Initiative permanent. Aligns the State's clean energy and carbon sequestration efforts with climate initiative goals. Amends membership and duties of the Task Force. Establishes a zero emissions clean economy target for the State. Makes an appropriation. (HB2182 CD1)

bill.abstract: Makes technical changes in other parts of GL c.159C to effectuate this redefinition.

bill.title: An Act prohibiting robocalls to all mobile telephone devices
bill.abstract: Amends provisions of GL c.159C (Telephone Solicitations) to authorize the Attorney General to enforce provisions against robocalls. In particular, the AG may initiate proceedings relating to a knowing violation or threatened knowing violation, and may include an injunction, a civil penalty or $1500-$10,000 for each knowing violation and additional relief in a court of competent jurisdiction. The attorney general may also issue investigative demands and subpoenas, administer oaths and conduct hearings in the course of investigating a violation. A person who has received more than 1 unsolicited telephonic call within a 12-month period by or on behalf of the same person or entity in violation of the prohibition on robocalls may also personally bring an action to enjoin the violation, to ...

status.statusval: House Session HS - 06/06/2018 11:00 AM House Chamber

bill.title: An Act updating Chapter 93H data security protections to include biometric information
bill.abstract: Amends GL 93H:1 to provide a definition for biometric indicators and to further provide that the same shall be considered personal information under GL Chapter 93H (Security Breaches).

bill.title: An Act requiring certain electronic toll collection fee notifications by the Massachusetts Department of Transportation
bill.abstract: ...Lane electronic tolling system. The Governor claims that the existing $100 threshold enacted by the legislature would be cost-prohibitive and violate the contract with the 3rd party vendor administering the system.

status.statusval: House Session HS - 06/06/2018 11:00 AM House Chamber

bill.title: An Act relative to a report on additional tax reporting requirements
bill.abstract: Department of Revenue by a year.Section 125 requires the Commissioner of Revenue to report on how he has used the authority granted in the budget to depart from federal requirements for 1099-K reporting (used to report income received from income received from electronic payments such as credit cards, debit cards, PayPal, and other third party payers). Currently, 1099-K reporting is carried out during the first two months of a calendar year, and the affected taxpayers may file the affected returns and pay their taxes as late as October of that calendar year. According to the Governor, a report as of March 15 of that calendar year will not be able to provide meaningful fiscal information. A reporting date of March 15, 2019 will allow for the preparation of a meaningful evaluation of the ...

status.statusval: House Session HS - 06/06/2018 11:00 AM House Chamber

bill.title: An Act relative to the electronic filing of certain forms used in property valuation
bill.abstract: Board of Assessors; the failure to follow instructions is to be considered equivalent to not filing or not responding.(New draft of HB1636. The new draft makes largely grammatical and technical changes to the previous text. Please note that neither the text of this bill of the previous version of the bill explicitly establish provisions relative to electronic filing, although the title of the new section relates to electronic filing requirements.)

status.statusval: House Session HS - 06/06/2018 11:00 AM House Chamber

bill.title: An Act relative to certain affordable housing in the Jamaica Plain section of the city of Boston
bill.abstract: Exempts the construction and development of the Armory Street public housing project in the Jamaica Plain section of the city of Boston from procurement and contracting laws; subjects the projects to various labor laws pertaining to construction of public works, including priority for veterans and citizens, use of job lists and job classifications, and wage determinations; further subjects the project to laws regulating construction and materials contracts if the project is funded in part by state or federal government low-income housing tax credits, grant, loan, or tax-exempt bonds; imposes requirements of the uniform procurement act if the project is subsequently conveyed to an entity that is not part of the Boston Housing Authority.

status.statusval: House Session HS - 06/06/2018 11:00 AM House Chamber

sponsor.name: Joint Committee on Telecommunications, Utilities & Energy

bill.title: An Act relative to hydro
bill.abstract: Amends GL 25A:11F relating to the renewable energy portfolio standard for retail electricity suppliers; defines relicensed hydroelectric facilities that receive a new license after January 1, 2018 under the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission Rules, as Class I renewable energy generating sources; requires relicensed hydroelectric facilities seeking to operate as a Class I renewable energy generating source to provide formal notice to the department of energy resources. (New draft of HB2697. The new draft replaces the prior text pertaining to net metering tariffs for small hydroelectric power net metering facilities, with new language relating to classification of relicensed hydroelectric facilities as Class I renewable energy generating sources.)

bill.title: An Act making appropriations for fiscal year 2019
bill.abstract: The \'printed-as-amended\' House-engrossed budget appropriates $44,589,746,517 in 1175 line-items. Broken down by category, this includes $38,717,595,403 in direct appropriations, $497,119,509 in chargebacks, $526,270,924 in reserve accounts, $564,472,641 in retained revenues, $2,596,231,508 in federal grants, and $1,688,056,532 in operating transfers. The largest items, as usual, include $5.7 billion for MassHealth managed care, $4.8 billion for Chapter 70 payments to cities and towns, $3.5 billion for MassHealth Senior Care, $2.6 billion for MassHealth fee for service payments, $2.1 billion for consolidated long term debt service, $2.1 billion for MassHealth affordable care act expansion populations, $1.7 billion for Group Insurance premium and plan costs, $1.1 billion for community ...

bill.title: An Act promoting climate change adaptation, environmental and natural resource protection, and investment in recreational assets and opportunity
bill.abstract: This substantial bill, comprising 103 printed pages, also includes 103 outside sections in addition to the appropriations.The largest items here include $413.9 million for DCR reservations, forests, parks, campgrounds, comfort stations, harbor islands and other facilities; $151. 8 million for a grant programs for land, soil, water and natural resource conservation, open space preservation, watershed remediation, coastal resource protection, and related items; $100.6 million for the design, construction, reconstruction, rehabilitation, retrofitting, repair or removal of state-owned dams; and $93.7 million for investment in water and air quality protection.The outside sections make a large number of technical changes, many of them dealing with the consolidation of civil penalties relative to ...

bill.abstract: Amends GL 111:70E, by requiring health care facilities that provide mastectomy surgery, lymph node dissection, or a lumpectomy to provide information to the patient concerning the option of reconstructive surgery; requires information provided to include the listed topics, including information about reconstructive options and their advantages and disadvantages, prior to receiving consent for surgery. (New draft HB1161, which eliminates required disclosure of health coverage benefits for reconstructive surgery and additionally makes technical and grammatical changes to the prior text.

bill.abstract: The Senate Ways & Means recommendations for FY2019 appropriates $44,413,184,994 in 1144 line-items. This includes $38,652,198,919 in direct appropriations, $451,120,034 in chargebacks, $513,933,284 in reserve accounts, $560,748,795 in retained revenue accounts, $2,562,111,835 in federal grants and $1,673,072,127 in operating transfers. \r\rThe billion dollar line-items include $5.6 for MassHealth Managed Care; $4.9 for Chapter 70 Payments to Cities and Towns; $3.5 for MassHealth Senior Care; $2.6 for MassHealth Fee for Service Payments; $2.1 for Consolidated Long Term Debt Service; $2.1 for MassHealth Affordable Care Act Expansion Populations; $1.7 for Group Insurance Premium and Plan Costs; $1.1 for Community Residential Services for Developmentally Disabled; and $1.0 for Unrestricted ...

Heineken|General|Trade Practices and License to Operate

bill.title: An Act relative to oral health access for MassHealth patients
bill.abstract: Adds new Section 45D to GL 112 to provide that the Medicaid dental reimbursement rates set by EOHHS may not be less than 80 per cent of the average dental reimbursement rates; further provides that no dentist may refuse a patient solely on the basis that the services for said patient are reimbursed by Medicaid; makes dentists who violate this provision subject to disciplinary action by the Board of Registration in Dentistry.

profile.pname: Astellas|Healthcare General|Change in Reimbursement for Medicaid

bill.title: An Act to promote the accessibility, quality and continuity of care for consumers of behavioral health, substance use disorder and mental health services
bill.abstract: Submits changes to GL 176O (Health insurance consumer protections) which seek to empower behavioral health, substance use disorder and mental health providers by allowing them to jointly negotiate with benefits carriers; seeks to improve competitive balance in the industry and increase access to behavioral health, substance use disorder and mental health services; establishes a new GL 176O:28, authorizing health care professionals that provide behavioral health, mental health, and substance abuse services to jointly negotiate with carriers and behavioral health managers in the listed areas, including amounts of payment, procedure codes, utlitizaiton review and clinical practice guidelines; states that such negotiations are immune from antitrust challenges; (Note: possible issue of federal ...

bill.title: An Act establishing Medicare for all in Massachusetts
bill.abstract: This substantial bill establishes a new chapter 175L, the Massachusetts Health Care Trust, in the General Laws, which would create a single-payer system for health care in Massachusetts. The bill establishes a Massachusetts Health Care Trust, which will be the single-payer body responsible for the collection and disbursement of funds required to provide health care services for every resident of the Commonwealth. Its 23 member board is to include representatives nominated by health care professionals, labor, senior citizens, single-payer advocates, people with disabilities and caregivers, children\'s advocates, providers of legal services for people of low-income; 8 people elected by the citizens of Massachusetts; and the Secretary of Health and Human Services, the Secretary of ...

profile.pname: Mylan|General Business Issues|Changes in State Licensing

bill.title: An Act relative to accountable care
bill.abstract: Adds new Section 78 to GL 118E (Division of Medical Assistance) to require all accountable care organizations that contract with the Division to report annually certain information; outlines the information to to be so disclosed.

profile.pname: Astellas|Healthcare General|Change in Reimbursement for Medicaid

bill.title: An Act to promote transparency in prescription drug prices
bill.abstract: Adds new sections to GL c.6D (Health Policy Commission) that requires the Commission, in collaboration with the Center for Health Information and Analysis, to annually identify up to 15 prescription drugs on which the State spends significant health care dollars and for which the wholesale acquisition cost has increased by 50% or more over the past five years or by 15% or more over the past 12 months, or is a new drug whose price may have a significant impact on the cost benchmark. For each prescription drug identified by the Commission, the Office of the Attorney General will require the drug\'s manufacturer to provide a justification for the increase in the wholesale acquisition cost of the drug. The AG, in turn, must provide an Annual Prescription Drug Transparency Report to the ...

profile.pname: Mylan|General Business Issues|Changes in State Licensing

bill.title: An Act relative to hospital closures and health planning
bill.abstract: Amends GL 6A:16T, the statute governing the health planning council and advisory committee, to update the purposes of such so as to reflect its continued operation. Further includes more types of organizations that are eligible to participate so as to better represent all of the different kinds of interested parties. Further identifies the purposes of the state health plan. Amends GL 6D:13 to require a material change investigation be completed upon notice of a closure of a hospital or essential health service. Amends GL 12C:8 to require the center for health information and analysis to identify and report on financially distressed hospitals. Amends GL 111:51G to require any hospital to provide 90 days notice to the department of public health before discontinuing an essential health ...

bill.title: An Act to establish a state epinephrine bulk purchase program
bill.abstract: Inserts GL 29:2WWWW to establish the Municipal Epinephrine Bulk Purchase Trust Fund, to be administered by DPH,to fund the Municipal Epinephrine Bulk Purchase Program; and provides that municipalities may join the program to purchase epinephrine for municipal first responder agencies and elementary and secondary schools located within the district.

bill.title: An Act benefitting the Community Hospital Reinvestment Trust Fund
bill.abstract: Adds provisions to GL 29:2TTTT (Community Hospital Reinvestment Trust Fund) to establish a Large Physicians Organizations Assessment that proportionally assesses not more than $20,000,000, in order to increase allotments into the Trust Fund, on independent non-profit physician organizations with more than 500 physician members, provided that such organizations are not controlled or owned by a licensed acute care hospital or hospital system; exempts any such organization from this assessment if their percentage of gross charges reimbursed by the state Office of Medicaid is equal to or greater than 15 per cent of their total charges for the fiscal year; further provides that such assessments be proportional to the relative to the Organization\'s annual commercially insured net patient ...

profile.pname: Astellas|Healthcare General|Change in Reimbursement for Medicaid

bill.title: An Act to promote transparency and cost control of pharmaceutical drug prices
bill.abstract: Adds new provisions to GL c.6D (Health Policy Commission) requiring the Commission, in consultation with the Center for Health Information and Analysis, to develop a list of critical prescription drugs for which there is a substantial public interest in understanding the development of its pricing. For each prescription drug that the commission places on the critical prescription drug list the manufacturers must provide to the Commission an enumerated list of particular information. This information will not be considered a public record and will not be subject to public disclosure. In addition, the Commission must identify those prescription drugs that, due to their cost, jeopardize the Commonwealth\'s ability to meet the statewide health care cost growth benchmark. If the Commission ...

profile.pname: Mylan|General Business Issues|Changes in State Licensing

bill.title: An Act relative to coverage for chronic illness
bill.abstract: Amends Chapter 58 of the Acts of 2006, \'An Act Providing Access to Affordable, Quality, Accountable Health Care\' to provide that no deductible or copay may be charged for the treatment of any chronic disease, illness, or condition. (Also known as GL 176J:5).

bill.title: An Act to ensure timely health care cost reporting
bill.abstract: Amends GL 12C:11 (Center for Health Care Information and Analysis:Timely Reporting of Information) to require the Center to assess penalties against a private payer, provider or provider organization that fails to provide information required by the statute; increases said penalties from $1,000 to $5,000 per week up to a maximum of $200,000 (current legal maximum is $50,000); allows a just cause exemption from the penalties; directs the Center to issue regulations defining just cause.

bill.title: An Act relative to patient centered access to behavioral health services in accountable care organizations
bill.abstract: Adds new provisions to GL c.6D (Health Policy Commission) to provide for \'patient centered\' access to behavioral health services in accountable care organizations. In particular, the bill requires that all Accountable Care Organizations offer \'patient navigation and care coordination services\' for patients with a diagnosed mental illness or substance use disorder (or those with symptoms that suggest a possible mental illness or substance use disorder as determined by a licensed health care provider). Services provided as part of the these programs are to include an enumerated set of eleven functions, including items such as performing an initial intake to assess the patient\'s needs, finding an appropriate provider and even assisting with navigating health insurance requirements. All ...

bill.title: An Act relative to health care non-discrimination
bill.abstract: Adds new Section 28 to GL 176O (Health Insurance Consumer Protections) setting forth the measures of total medical expense to be used by carriers to establish an alternative payment arrangement; requires each carrier to file data with the center for health information and analysis on such arrangements; defines alternative payment arrangement.

bill.title: An Act relative to the sustainability of public health dental hygienists through adequate reimbursements
bill.abstract: Amends GL 112:51 relative to dental hygienists by changing the current provisions that establish that a public health dental hygienists is to be directly reimbursed for services administered in a public health setting by Medicaid or the Commonwealth Care health insurance program, but except as required by federal Medicaid law, is not not seek reimbursement from any other insurance or 3rd party payor. This bill strikes out the provisions that she will be reimbursed by Medicaid, or that she can seek reimbursement from 3rd party payors when required by federal Medicaid law. (Identical to HB 1989).

An Act making appropriations for fiscal year 2019
bill.abstract: The Senate-engrossed (printed as amended) version of the fiscal year 2019 main budget appropriates $44,561,868,414 in 1165 line-items. This includes $38,722,973,979 in direct appropriations, $523,199,865 in chargebacks, $516,998,284 in reserve accounts, $560,648,795 in retained revenue accounts, $2,564,408,364 in federal grants, and $1,673,639,127 in operating transfers.\r\rThe largest items, as usual, are mostly health care, local aid and debt related, and include $5.7 billion in the MassHealth Managed Care account; $4.9 billion in the Chapter 70 payments to cities and towns account; $3.6 billion in the MassHealth Senior Care account; $2.6 billion in the MassHealth Fee for Service Payments account; $2.2 billion in the Consolidated Long Term Debt Service account; $2.1 billion in the ...

bill.title: Enacts the Empowering People in Rights Enforcement (EMPIRE) Worker Protection Act
bill.abstract: Enacts the ""Empowering People in Rights Enforcement (EMPIRE) Worker Protection Act""; relates to the delegation of state enforcement authority to private actors; authorizes an aggrieved employee or employees or a representative organization to initiate a public enforcement action on behalf of the commissioner for any provision of the labor law, or any regulation promulgated thereunder, that provides for a civil penalty to be assessed and collected by the commissioner for a violation of the labor law.

bill.abstract: Prohibits the sale and distribution of flavored e-liquid which creates a distinguishable flavor or aroma for use in e-cigarettes.

bill.title: Relates to requiring a consumer credit reporting agency to offer identity theft prevention and mitigation services in the case of a breach of the security of such agency's system
bill.abstract: Prohibits fees for security freezes by consumer credit reporting agencies in the case of a breach of information; prohibits fees for subsequent removal or temporary lift of a security freeze, requires a consumer credit reporting agency which has suffered a breach to provide free identity theft protection services.

bill.title: Relates to telepsychiatry
bill.abstract: Relates to telepsychiatry and requires a study, report and recommendations regarding geriatric social isolation.

status.statusval: REPORTED REFERRED TO WAYS AND MEANS

bill.title: Enacts the ""toll payer protection act""; repealer
bill.abstract: Enacts the ""toll payer protection act"" to establish a New York toll payers' bill of rights; provides that any person, firm, corporation, or other entity who is charged with the payment of a cashless toll fee in the state of New York shall have the option to be notified by text message or electronic mail that such fee has been so charged, the entity to which such fee must be paid, and the date by when such fee must be paid; further provides for the establishment of a payment plan for the payment of a toll fee and any related penalties; makes related provisions.

bill.title: Relates to prohibitions on single-use plastic straws in restaurants
bill.abstract: Requires that restaurants only provide single-use plastic straws to customers when explicitly requested by the customer or when selected by the consumer from a self-service dispenser.

bill.abstract: Relates to authorizing custom liquor production for a non-licensed individual by farm distilleries; establishes conditions for such production including that such custom liquor shall not be offered for sale.

bill.title: Electronic visitation; state correctional facilities.
bill.abstract: Electronic visitation; state correctional facilities. Authorizes the Director of the Department of Corrections to prescribe reasonable rules regarding electronic visitation systems and the collection of fees for the use of such systems. The bill provides that any facility that uses such a system shall not prohibit in-person visitation.

status.statusval: Governor: Acts of Assembly Chapter text (CHAP0066)

bill.title: Health insurance; individual coverage, short-term policies.
bill.abstract: Health insurance; short-term plans. Authorizes health insurance carriers in the Commonwealth to offer short-term health plans. Short-term health plans are defined as plans with a duration of 364 days or less. Short-term health plans are required to include a specified disclaimer. The bill is contingent on the adoption of federal regulations expanding the availability of short-term health plans.
